posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: During a playoff match at the 10,000 Lakes Regional competition, our team experienced an issue where the 5V rail on our Rio DIO ports completely died. This occurred likely due to a collision with a defensive bot. Given the upcoming release of the new robot controller, we probably won’t pursue obtaining a replacement. However, we discovered that we can successfully use our Voltage Regulator Module (VRM) for power instead. We’re curious if this is a common failure mode that others have encountered before.

posts.name: Aaron
posts.cooked: Are there 10 million lakes? Anyway, are any of the status lights different? Are there any faults for the Rio on Driver Station?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 4269 Student Captain and Electrical Lead

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: Issues may arise if the 5v rail becomes shorted to ground or connected to another voltage source, such as 12v. The power supply is relatively fault intolerant, leading many teams to encounter problems like metal shavings from drilling while installed on robots, which can cause this issue. Some teams have resolved the problem by thoroughly cleaning their devices, while others have faced persistent issues despite repeated cleaning, requiring them to seek an alternative 5v power source.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: There are no various status lights; the only issue with the RIO is that the 5V is not functioning correctly.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We did have metal shavings at one point, which we vacuumed out. Although you might be right, the issue was delayed, and it could have possibly caused permanent damage.

We encountered an issue with a Rio experiencing problems related to its 5V rail. At our initial setup, we installed limit switches and mistakenly connected one wire to the signal and another to the 5V supply. Normally, this shouldn’t function due to an internal pull-up resistor on the DIO pin, but remarkably, it worked until one of our practice sessions, where the Rio suddenly produced an unrecoverable error. This later evolved into a power fault during debugging.
What color is your power status light? If it's red, that means there's a chip in the ports shorting it. If it's green, it indicates something else.

link_counts.title: Status Light Quick Reference — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Issac Woo
posts.cooked: I also want to offer this: try unscrewing your roboRIO apart, carefully, and vacuuming and using isopropyl alcohol to clean up anything inside there as well. You’ll be surprised how much dust is in there!

Something like that happened to us. Our RSL port just completely died randomly during competition. All the ports on the rio were covered with electrical tape, so nothing should have been able to get in and damage it.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
This can happen if the 5V rail is shorted to ground or another source, such as 12V. The power source is not extremely fault-tolerant, often leading to issues like metal shavings from drilling causing similar problems during installation.  

I’m curious about devices more fault-tolerant than the roboRIO, especially regarding whether it continues to operate a particular pin with a direct short. The fact that most issues can be resolved by cleaning debris without releasing "magic smoke" suggests greater fault tolerance compared to many devices.  

The RoboRIO is designed to handle such faults gracefully. It isolates problematic pins automatically when a short occurs, preventing damage and keeping the system operational. Its design also allows for easy maintenance without extensive repairs.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: Off-highway vehicle controllers designed for consumer use rather than industrial applications differ in requirements despite sharing a similar design approach to the roboRIO. Every input/output (I/O) line is individually short-to-high and short-to-ground fault tolerant, including external 5V sources. In the event of a fault, the affected pin is typically returned to a neutral or off state to prioritize safety considerations. However, there are rare scenarios where simultaneously shorting one pin to high and another to ground can create a dead short across the intrinsic body diode of an output driver chip, potentially damaging it. Such incidents have been reported, though some users have managed to recover by cleaning metal shavings. Additionally, there have been instances where students accidentally shorted supply rails, leading to issues. While all designs have inherent limits that must be respected to avoid harm, the roboRIO represented an improvement over earlier systems. The newly introduced '27 control system, described as fully 100% S2H (short-to-high) and S2G (short-to-ground) tested, appears to take this a step further with its enhanced safety features. This level of electrical circuit design and validation seems particularly well-suited for the FIRST teaching environment, where such rigorous safety measures are both necessary and educational.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Did you know you can jump-start a medium-sized motor grader using an arc welder? That kind of fault-tolerant system would likely require careful inspection before attempting repairs. To OP: the RIO on my bench at home has a fried 5v rail. It’s the second one our team has created in the last four years. No amount of cleanout has fixed the issue. One more year, then we’ll have different problems to complain about!

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: 10,000,000 lakes You know, I had this friend in college who insisted Wisconsin has more lakes than Minnesota. OP, there’s a good chance you have a short somewhere. Most (if not all) of the 5V pins on a RIO come from the same internal rail, so you can’t just unplug a few things. Unplug everything from the RIO except for power and check if you can measure 5V on it. If you see 5V, something you plugged into the RIO is shorting it out. Don’t plug anything back in until you identify what caused the short. RIOs are generally quite resilient compared to devices like motor controllers, but they’re still delicate. If you don’t see 5V with everything unplugged, replace the RIO and troubleshoot it separately from the robot. Before installing a new RIO, inspect the wiring that was previously connected to it for potential shorts—it’s possible a short in your wiring damaged the RIO’s 5V rail, and you wouldn’t want another RIO to suffer the same fate. Metal shavings are typically the cause of this issue. The worst action you can take in this situation is to continue using the RIO without addressing the problem. The concern is that metal shavings may migrate elsewhere and damage the RIO completely. Once you’ve checked the rest of your wiring, swap the RIO units, disassemble the faulty one, and clean it. To maintain ESD safety, avoid using brushes or cloths unless absolutely necessary, especially when dealing with significant buildup that can’t be removed otherwise.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I may be mistaken, but if I remember correctly, two years ago we opened up our Rio with a fried 5V bus caused by a short circuit to the battery. Most of the board was conformal coated to a decent thickness.

I fully agree to stopping use and identifying the issue, but I am wondering whether metal shavings deeper than a certain point could genuinely be a problem. 

I recall that the conformal coating did not cover the I/O pins themselves, but it did start covering a few millimeters beyond the mechanical openings. 

However, I might be confusing this with another controller I disassembled recently, so I cannot be entirely sure.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.  

Everyone is surprised at the 32V jump start voltage levels for a 12V system, or charging system load dump transients! Who knows what someone might rig up out in the field to try to get themselves home—I’ve heard of welders being used before but never seen it.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked: quite to the dismay of automotive electronics engineers everywhere… and Brandon Hjelstrom. On a separate note, I sure hope the new Mobile Robot Controller is like potted or something. I think the roboRIO is especially bad with the giant gaps in the plastic around the DIO, but I wonder if material sneaks through the small gaps around the other ports? We tape over everything and still get internal shorts. Perhaps our elevator is generating especially tiny particulate. We already know it won’t have sealed industrial/automotive connectors which is a bit disappointing (no one really uses them in FIRST though), but at least if they use actual Molex SL connectors instead of a header strip, there isn’t as much of a gaping hole in the case. I’m not sure why it’s only the RIO we ever have this issue with, maybe the conformal coating is too thin or something? We weren’t just getting the 5V short fault, it wasn’t even booting until we took it apart and blew it out.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We finally got back in the shop yesterday, and apparently there was a metal shaving we missed at comp. It was stuck deep inside, so we didn’t notice it when we vacuumed the area. We used compressed air in the shop to blow it out, and the problem has been resolved.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: The Rio has internal overcurrent protection on the 5V DIO ports (1A) and also the 6V PWM ports (2.2A). This is intentional to prevent damage to electronics from metal shavings. We tape exposed openings as much as possible. Between events, we remove the Rio and open the case to clean debris. Despite being well sealed, debris still sometimes gets inside the case.
